projectDesc.p: "Chen Dynasty Monk Huisi of the Great Southern Peak Hengshan" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: 釋慧思。姓俗李氏。項城 武津人也。
app.rdg: Monk Huisi, whose lay surname was Li, was a person from Xiangcheng, in Wujin county.

app.lem: 兒時因夢梵僧勸令入佛道。
app.rdg: As a child he dreamed that an Indian monk urged him to take up the Buddhist path.

app.lem: 又夢數僧訓以齋戒日惟一食。不受別供。
app.rdg: In another dream, many monks trained him in the ways of renouncing food and drink. He ate just once a day, refusing other offerings.

app.lem: 時見朋類。誦法華經。情深樂重。
app.rdg: One time, observing his companions reciting the Dharma Flower Scripture, he felt profound emotions and intense joy.
Until then he had never recited it.

app.lem: 日從他借經。於空塚中。獨自看之。
app.rdg: On that day he borrowed the scripture from someone and, alone among abandoned grave mounds, he read it.
With no-one to teach it to him, he wept day and night.
These tombs were home to inhuman creatures.
His share of fears was not small.
He therefore moved to the old city wall and carved out a hollow space to live within.
In the day he begged for food.
At night he did not sleep.
Facing the scripture, shedding tears, he prostrated without rest.
In the summer of that year it rained heavily.
Rainwater made his hollow wet and steamy.
His entire body became so swollen with dropsy that he could no longer move.
Yet he turned his mind urgently toward the scripture and his mental power filled him with strength.
All of a sudden, his condition evaporated and his health was restored, as before.

app.lem: 夢普賢乘六牙白象。來摩頂而去。
app.rdg: He dreamed that Samantabhadra, riding a six-tusked white elephant, came to him, rubbed his head, and then left.

app.lem: 法華一部。曾未識文。自然解了。
app.rdg: Every part of the Dharma Flower Scripture whose words he once could not comprehend, he now freely understood.

app.lem: 所摩之處。自然隱起如肉髻。
app.rdg: The place where Samantabhadra had touched him freely rose up, like a flesh topknot.

app.lem: 凡十年之中。誦法華聲不輟。
app.rdg: For ten whole years he recited the Dharma Flower, the sound of his voice unceasing.

app.lem: 復悟法華三昧大乘法門。
app.rdg: Consequently, he realized the Dharma Flower Samādhi, Gateway to the Dharma of the Great Vehicle:
the level of clear understanding, the stage which completely purifies the six sense faculties.

app.lem:
出傳中。
Excerpted from 法華傳記 Fahua zhuanji, T vol. 51 no. 2068, 59a29-59b13.
